me.tatarka.ipromise.func

Class Filters

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.tatarka.ipromise.func.Filters

  • public final class Filters
extends java.lang.Object
    Some useful filters to use with Promise.then(Filter).
    See Also:
    Filter

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static <T> Filter<T> dedup()
      Filters out consecutive duplicates.
      static <T> Filter<T> equal(T value)
      Filters out items not equal to the given value.
      static <T> Filter<T> not(Filter<T> filter)
      Inverts a filter so that if the given filter accepts an item it will be rejected and vice-versa.
      static <T> Filter<T> rateLimit(long timespan, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
      Filters out items so that you will never get two consecutive ones within the given timespan.
      static <T> Filter<T> unique()
      Filters out any duplicates.

    • Method Detail

      • unique

        public static <T> Filter<T> unique()
        Filters out any duplicates. For example, [1, 2, 1, 3, 2] will become [1, 2, 3]. This has to store all values it comes across to check duplicates, so use cautiously.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the item type
        Returns:
        the Filter

      • dedup

        public static <T> Filter<T> dedup()
        Filters out consecutive duplicates. For example, [1, 1, 2, 2, 3] will become [1, 2, 3].
        Type Parameters:
        T - the item type
        Returns:
        the Filter

      • rateLimit

        public static <T> Filter<T> rateLimit(long timespan,
                                      java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Filters out items so that you will never get two consecutive ones within the given timespan. This is useful, if you want to sample a source at a lower rate.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the item type
        Parameters:
        timespan - the timespan
        unit - the unit of the timespan
        Returns:
        the Filter

      • equal

        public static <T> Filter<T> equal(T value)
        Filters out items not equal to the given value. This is useful if you only care about a subset of events.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the item type
        Parameters:
        value - the value to check equality
        Returns:
        the Filter

      • not

        public static <T> Filter<T> not(Filter<T> filter)
        Inverts a filter so that if the given filter accepts an item it will be rejected and vice-versa.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the item type
        Parameters:
        filter - the filter to invert
        Returns:
        the Filter
